channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israeli Jets Bomb Sites in Yemen Linked to Iran-Backed Houthis
item.description: The strike was retaliation for a drone attack launched from Yemen a day earlier, which evaded Israel’s defenses and hit a building in Tel Aviv, killing one person.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman, Shuaib Almosawa and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Houthi Media Center, via Agence-France Presse - Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by a Houthi media source shows a large fire in the Yemeni port city of Hodeidah after Israeli airstrikes on Saturday.

item.title: Did Police in Kenya Catch a Serial Killer or Coerce a Confession?
item.description: After at least 10 sacks with body parts were found in a dump, a suspect was said to admit to 42 murders. But some doubt the case, and people with missing loved ones say the police were slow to help.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Brian Otieno
item.media:credit: Brian Otieno for The New York Times

item.title: The Olympics Is Transforming Their Neighborhood. And Kicking Them Out.
item.description: The Games brought billions to redevelop this Paris suburb. What will the thousands of homeless people who live there do?
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Immigrants sitting together inside the so-called Squat Gambetta in Seine-Saint-Denis, a suburban area east of Paris.

item.title: How the U.S. Played a Role in Venezuela’s Election
item.description: The Biden administration helped prod the Venezuelan government to hold elections on July 28. Now, it is watching to see if the vote will be free and fair.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of the opposition candidate Edmundo González going house to house this month showing the presidential ballot to neighbors in El Junco, Venezuela.

item.title: The Buried Book That Helped Ukraine’s Literary Revival
item.description: To keep it from Russian forces, a writer hid his last manuscript under a cherry tree. Its rediscovery became part of a flowering of interest in Ukrainian literature.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Maria Varenikova and Finbarr O’Reilly
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Burned books inside the printing plant that was struck by Russian missiles last month.

item.title: Divisive Far-Right Politician in Ukraine Is Fatally Shot
item.description: Iryna Farion, a former lawmaker, was known for controversial campaigns to discredit Russian-speaking Ukrainians.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Iryna Farion, a linguistics professor and former lawmaker, in Lviv, Ukraine, in 2022.

item.title: Dozens Dead or Missing After China Highway Collapse
item.description: It was the second such rain-related disaster in less than three months, as extreme weather challenges the country’s extensive network of newly built expressways.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: A photograph released by China’s Xinhua news agency showing the broken bridge on Saturday.

item.title: To Deter Day-Trippers, Venice Tested a €5 Entrance Fee. Did Visitors Stay Away?
item.description: The mayor said preliminary data suggested that the experiment was a success. But the program brought in far more money than predicted, which critics called proof of failure.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Matteo de Mayda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Inspectors checking tourists in Venice last month to verify that they had paid an entrance fee.

item.title: Bangladesh Orders Curfew to Quell Deadly Protests
item.description: For weeks, university students have been protesting a quota system for government jobs. Suppression led to a cycle of violence and now a paralyzing curfew.
item.dc:creator: Saif Hasnat and Anupreeta Das
item.media:description: Police facing off with protesters in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Friday.

item.title: Death of Vietnam’s Top Leader Raises Questions of Succession
item.description: The country’s political workings are notably opaque, but for now the president, who was until recently minister of public security, is carrying out the duties of general secretary.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock
item.media:description: President To Lam of Vietnam in Hanoi last month.

item.title: The Bangladesh Protests, in Photos and Videos
item.description: Students, armed mainly with sticks, have been demonstrating for days against a quota system for government jobs they consider unfair. Dozens have died in the violence.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Dhaka, Bangladesh’s capital, on Thursday.

item.title: Conflict in Western Congo Leaves Thousands Dead and Displaced
item.description: Overshadowed by fighting in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo, a dispute in the west between two ethnic groups has resulted in thousands of civilians killed and more than 550,000 displaced near the capital, Kinshasa.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: WSJ Reporter Evan Gershkovich Faces 16 Years in Russian Prison for Espionage
item.description: The Wall Street Journal reporter’s trial on espionage charges was widely viewed as a sham outside Russia. But the verdict could set the stage for a prisoner exchange.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: The Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich standing in a glass cage in a courtroom in Yekaterinburg, Russia, last month.

item.title: What Evan Gershkovich Might Face Inside Russia’s Notorious Prisons
item.description: Evan Gershkovich, The Wall Street Journal reporter, was convicted on fabricated charges and is expected to serve time in one of the country’s infamous prisons.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Eve Sampson
item.media:description: Evan Gershkovich, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal, on Friday during the verdict announcement at the Sverdlovsk Regional Court in Yekaterinburg, Russia.

item.title: The World’s Most Fashionable Judoka Is Looking for Clothes in His Size
item.description: Teddy Riner has long had trouble finding stylish apparel for his 6-foot-8 frame. Could it be time to create his own line?
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Teddy Riner, with his wife, Luthna Plocus, at the Balenciaga show at Paris Fashion Week in March 2024. He’s wearing Balenciaga.

item.title: Thomas Neff, Who Turned Soviet Warheads Into Electricity, Dies at 80
item.description: An M.I.T. physicist, he engineered an East-West deal that reduced nuclear threats and produced one of the greatest peace dividends of all time.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad

item.title: ‘There’s No Way to Turn Yourself In’: Migrants Rethink Routes to U.S.
item.description: In Tapachula, Mexico, migrants en route to the United States are being forced to reroute their journeys after President Biden’s executive order suspending and limiting asylum requests, and human smugglers are profiting.
item.dc:creator: Alex Pena, Benjamin Alfaro and Amy Marino

item.title: Houthi Drone Strike Highlights Dilemmas for Israel
item.description: Israel has few options to retaliate for the attack in Tel Aviv, which made clear the weakness of its air defense system against unmanned aircraft and heightened concerns about the threat of Iranian-backed militias.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A building in Tel Aviv that was struck on Friday.

item.title: ‘Twisters’ and the Appeal of the Sequel
item.description: When a sequel comes out, it can be an occasion to reaffirm why you love the original.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Much Is Still Unknown as Listeria Again Takes Canadian Lives
item.description: While a listeria contamination of 18 nondairy milk alternatives has killed two people and sickened 10 more, Danone seems to be concealing a key fact.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Neither Danone nor the Canadian government will say what company made the nondairy milk linked to two deaths.

item.title: Blinken Says Gaza Cease-Fire Deal Is ‘Inside the 10-Yard Line’
item.description: The national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, was more cautious as both spoke ahead of next week’s visit to Washington by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, the national security adviser, and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said nothing about how the president would juggle the crisis engulfing his re-election bid with managing the tense relationship with the Israeli prime minister.

item.title: Houthis Launch Deadly Drone Strike on Tel Aviv, Evading Israel’s Defenses
item.description: At least one person was killed and eight others injured in a predawn attack on Friday. The Israeli military said it was investigating why it “did not identify it, attack it and intercept it.”
item.dc:creator: Gabby Sobelman, Aaron Boxerman, Ronen Bergman, Lara Jakes and Erin Mendell
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: The White House Has a Plan to Slash Plastic Use in the U.S.
item.description: The government said it would phase out its purchases of single-use plastics, a significant step because it is the biggest buyer of consumer goods in the world.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.category: White House Council on Environmental Quality
item.media:description: The goal of the administration’s plan is to reduce demand for plastics and encourage a market for reusable or compostable alternatives.

item.title: Boat Fire off Haitian Coast Leaves At Least 40 Migrants Dead
item.description: The boat was carrying over 80 people and bound for Turks and Caicos. The disaster underscores the gang-fueled crisis that has spurred many Haitians to leave.
item.dc:creator: David C. Adams and James Wagner

item.title: What’s Left for France’s Left?
item.description: Two weeks ago a coalition of left-wing parties came first in the legislative elections. Now some wonder whether it will have any power at all.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Jean-Luc Mélenchon, the leader of the far-left France Unbowed party. The parties of a left-wing coalition have been fighting among themselves after their victories in the country’s parliamentary elections.

item.title: Canada Pledges to Hit NATO Military Spending Target by 2032
item.description: The country’s struggle to reach an informal military spending target highlights how difficult it is for the alliance to quickly bolster its abilities.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada, center, at the NATO Summit in Washington this month. He pledged to reach a 2 percent target by 2032.

item.title: Is Your Flight Delayed by the Tech Outage? Here’s What You Need to Know.
item.description: While service is slowly recovering, flights are still being canceled and delays can stretch for hours. Here’s the latest on airlines, airports and cruises, as well as your rights and how to reach customer service.
item.dc:creator: Derek M. Norman, Christine Chung and Ceylan Yeğinsu
item.media:description: Crowds at Baltimore/Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport on Friday, caught up in a technology outage that affected a worldwide range of systems, including 911 services and airline check-ins.

item.title: A Post-Euros, Post-Copa Mailbag
item.description: Euro 2024 memories, Copa América issues and the enduring allure of a winning goal.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Lionel Messi and Argentina capped a long summer with a trophy.

item.title: U.K. Says It’s Restoring Funding to the U.N. Agency That Aids Palestinians
item.description: The country’s new foreign secretary said that the agency, UNRWA, had taken steps to ensure that it meets “the highest standards of neutrality.”
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Damage at a vacant UNRWA complex in Gaza City this month.

item.title: Nguyen Phu Trong, Powerful Vietnamese Leader, Is Dead at 80
item.description: Known for his “blazing furnace” anticorruption campaign, Mr. Trong consolidated power in one of the world’s few remaining Communist dictatorships.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Hoang Dinh Nam/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Nguyen Phu Trong, center, at the Vietnam Communist Party’s 11th National Congress in Hanoi, in 2011, at which he was voted to be the party’s new general secretary.

item.title: Zelensky Is First Foreign Leader to Visit U.K. Cabinet Since Clinton
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky briefed Keir Starmer’s top team in an appearance designed to showcase Britain’s steadfast support for Ukraine in its war against Russia.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain welcoming the Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelensky, to 10 Downing Street in London on Friday.

item.title: America’s Unstable Politics
item.description: A remarkable day for both Donald Trump and President Biden highlights our new era of political uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump onstage at the Republican National Convention.

item.title: Why Do Kind Strangers Return Our Wallets?
item.description: Whoever you are, we appreciate it.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Jun Michael Park
item.media:description: The writer’s wallet perches on a balcony in Seoul, a few months after it was lost and found in London.

item.title: Putin Counted on Waning U.S. Interest in Ukraine. It Might Be a Winning Bet.
item.description: The arc of American foreign policy could be moving closer to the Russian president’s view of it. But he has been wrong before about the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in the Kremlin in March.

item.title: Is She the Oldest Person in the Amazon Rainforest?
item.description: The life of Varî Vãti Marubo shows how much life has changed for the rainforest’s Indigenous tribes — and how much has stayed the same.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Victor Moriyama
item.media:credit: Victor Moriyama for The New York Times

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: A pivotal moment in the White House race.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Donald Trump gave a speech in Milwaukee accepting the Republican presidential nomination, as screens showed images from the attempt on his life last weekend.

item.title: A Border Crossing Shuttered for Months Traps the Sick and Wounded in Gaza
item.description: The Rafah crossing to Egypt has been closed since Israel captured it in early May, blocking the only route out of the territory for thousands of Palestinians who desperately need medical care.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: A 9-year-old Palestinian girl who suffered burns during an Israeli bombardment was treated at Al-Aqsa Martyrs Hospital in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza, in June.

item.title: Italian Monks Rebuild Quake-Ravaged Monastery, Giving Hope to Region
item.description: Eight years after devastating earthquakes ravaged central Italy, the reopening of a monastery is an inspiration for an area still struggling to recover.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Alessandro Penso for The New York Times
item.media:description: One of the reconstructed buildings at the monastery, which perches on a green hillside over Norcia, a town in central Italy.

item.title: A Tip Sheet to Help Decipher American Politics
item.description: With the presidential campaign in a stretch of discord and profound uncertainty, here are a few pieces that provide understanding and context.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: At the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, Wis., on Wednesday.

item.title: Large Earthquake Rocks Northern Chile
item.description: There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage after the 7.4 magnitude earthquake.
item.dc:creator: Andrés R. Martínez

item.title: Houthis Claim Responsibility for Deadly Tel Aviv Explosion
item.description: An Israeli military official said the military was still investigating where the drone was launched from.
item.dc:creator: Gabby Sobelman, Aaron Boxerman, Adam Rasgon, Rawan Sheikh Ahmad and Erin Mendell
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: Pressure Builds on Netanyahu as Visit to Washington Nears
item.description: A planned speech to Congress by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has made clear the serious divisions he faces back home.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Protesters in Tel Aviv on Thursday calling for the release of the hostages held by Hamas.

item.title: Friday Briefing: U.S. Presidential Race at a Crossroads
item.description: Plus, security failures at the Trump rally.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Donald Trump will address the final day of the Republican convention.

item.title: Dig at Meloni’s Height Could Cost Reporter in Italy 5,000 Euros
item.description: A lawsuit that Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni won is one of several she has filed against critics. Press-freedom groups say it is a concerning practice.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni of Italy at the Group of 7 summit in Fasano last month. A judge found a journalist guilty of defaming her over an insult.

item.title: Germany Promised to Step Up Militarily. Its Budget Says Differently.
item.description: After Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Chancellor Olaf Scholz vowed a revolution in defense strategy. But the math is not adding up.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany at a NATO summit in Washington this month.

item.title: World Leaders Mull a Potential Second Term for Trump
item.description: Some governments are taking concrete steps to prepare for the possible return of the former U.S. president.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
item.media:description: With Donald J. Trump consistently polling ahead of President Biden, some governments around the world are taking concrete steps to prepare for the possibility of a second Trump administration.

item.title: At 5, She Picked Up Chess as a Pandemic Hobby. At 9, She’s a Prodigy.
item.description: Bodhana Sivanandan, a fourth-grader, has become one of England’s best players just a few years after discovering chess during pandemic lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bodhana Sivanandan will represent England at the Chess Olympiad.

item.title: U.K. Failed in Handling of Covid Pandemic, Inquiry Report Says
item.description: The British authorities prepared for the wrong pandemic, with an outdated plan overly focused on influenza, an official investigation reported.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Royal Free Hospital in London in March 2020. The report is the first from an inquiry established in 2021 by the then prime minister, Boris Johnson.

item.title: A Daily Pill to Prevent S.T.I.s? It May Work, Scientists Say.
item.description: A common antibiotic, doxycycline, greatly reduced cases of syphilis, gonorrhea and chlamydia when taken every day, a study found.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: The C.D.C. recommends that gay and bisexual men and transgender women who have had an S.T.I. in the last year or who may be at risk for one take doxycycline within 72 hours of unprotected sex.

item.title: Student Protests in Bangladesh Turn Deadly: What to Know
item.description: Violent clashes have erupted between the police and students protesting a quota system used to fill coveted civil service jobs.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Saif Hasnat
item.media:description: Clashes between the police and people who oppose a quota system n Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh, on Thursday.

item.title: Von der Leyen Secures Second E.U. Term, but It’s a New World Out There
item.description: The German conservative, a steadfast U.S. ally, gained European Parliament approval to lead the European Commission for another five years. She’ll face tumult at home and abroad.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen addressing the European Parliament in Strasbourg, France, on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine Loses Hard-Won Position Near Dnipro River in the South
item.description: Soldiers and military analysts said an operation to establish a foothold on the river’s Russian-controlled eastern bank was bloody and hard to justify.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier with an anti aircraft cannon in the Kherson region last month.

item.title: The Myth of Migrant Crime
item.description: Republicans suggest that immigrants are especially likely to be criminals. The data shows the opposite.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants waiting to be taken to a shelter in Chicago.

item.title: Pressure Mounts on Netanyahu to Seal a Cease-Fire Deal Before Speech to Congress
item.description: The Israeli leader’s speech before a divided Congress next week is likely to be contentious, particularly if he does not close a deal with Hamas to end the war before he travels to Washington.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel at the Knesset, Israel’s Parliament, in Jerusalem on Wednesday.

item.title: France Parliament Re-elects Yaël Braun-Pivet for National Assembly President
item.description: A left-wing bloc that won the most seats in legislative elections this month called the re-election of Yaël Braun-Pivet, an ally of President Emmanuel Macron, a denial of democracy.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and Emma Bubola
item.media:description: Yaël Braun-Pivet, a centrist ally of President Emmanuel Macron, ascends the podium after winning re-election as president of France’s National Assembly on Thursday in Paris.

item.title: America’s Allies in Middle East See Some Advantages in Potential 2nd Trump Presidency
item.description: As Republicans meet this week for their convention, leaders in Israel, Saudi Arabia and Egypt are considering what a second Trump presidency could mean for their domestic and regional agendas.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Vivian Yee and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Then-President Donald J. Trump met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in 2020.
